text:
Situation A. Playing Ball?

At lunch, Kaleb and his friends discuss whether to play kickball, soccer, baseball, or dodgeball. Ethan, Ava, and Beno make suggestions for how to decide which game to play.

  • Decide whether each suggestion is a fair way to make the decision. Explain your thinking.
  • If the suggestion is not fair, how would you change the rules to make it fair.

tiles.title: Ethan's Spinner with 4 types of games

text: Fair since each section of the spinner has the same angle or area.

Ava’s Suggestion

We can roll a number cube.

If it lands on:

  • a multiple of 2, we play kickball.
  • a multiple of 3, we play soccer.
  • a prime number, we play baseball.
  • a factor of 5, we play dodgeball.

Not fair.

The results have the different probabilities. Also, some results represent more than one game selection. It a 3 is rolled, it could mean playing kickball, soccer, or baseball.

P(multiple of 2 2,4,6) = 3/6

P(multiple of 3 3,6) = 2/6

P(prime number 2,3,5) = 3/6

P(factor of 5  1,5) = 2/6

Possible Answer

Assign each game to a single number. Roll until you get one of the numbers.

For example,

1 represents kickball,

2 represents soccer,

3 represents baseball,

4 represents dodgeball.

Beno’s Suggestion

We put straws in a container.

2 red straws

2 yellow straws

3 green straws

3 purple straws

If the straw we draw is:

  • red, we play soccer.
  • yellow, we play baseball.
  • green, we play dodgeball.
  • purple, we play kickball.

Not fair since the number of straws in the container for each color is not the same. It is more likely the students will play dodgeball or kickball than play any other sport.

Possible Answer

Change to have the same number of straws for each color/sport.

Situation B. What’s Fair

  • Students discuss whether Beno’s suggestion in Situation A is fair. Who is correct? Explain.
Moe: 'I want to play soccer, but I think Beno’s suggestion is not fair since soccer has less chance of occurring than dodgeball or kickball'
Suri: 'I also want to play soccer. I think Beno’s suggestion is fair, since there are two chances that a red straw will be drawn, which means I play soccer. '
Moe is correct. There is chance to draw a red straw, but it is a smaller probability than drawing a green or purple.
• If Moe wants to play soccer, which method should she choose? Explain.

Situation C. Choosing a Mascot

The students need to choose one of the sixty 6th graders to wear the mascot costume on field day. Huey and Sal are texting about it. Which plan is fair? Explain.

Sal’s suggestion is fair if the first block corresponds to a student’s tens digit and the second block corresponds to a student’s ones digit. Note that 0 is represented by 00, 5 by 05, and so on.

Huey’s suggestion is not fair. Some students do not even have a chance

of winning (for example, students 1–9) because the smallest number on a number cube is 1. It is impossible to get a sum that is less than 10 when rolling 10 number cubes.
